{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3343936,"name":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","username":"Billfred","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T12:29:01.818Z","cooked":"

This past weekend at PCH Charleston, 1293’s Kitbot encountered a scenario we called “the ring toss problem”: a note that got over the top of our amp mechanism, which you just can’t shake off on the field. And since you’re limited to possessing one note, that basically nukes your scoring capabilities for the match.

We resolved this by adding a blocker panel to the back of our amp mechanism made out of corrugated plastic, which makes it impossible for a note to stick there. At worst, it’ll hang on one side and you can shake it off with the most basic of spin moves. And yes, this stays well clear of the shooting mechanism.

IMG_36561920×1440 142 KB

IMG_36581920×1440 178 KB

IMG_36591920×1440 132 KB

The bill of materials is cheap and Everybot-friendly:

  • 3.25"x16.5" of corrugated plastic. The precise dimensions probably aren’t super important. Note that we cut it with the ribs (flutes? corrugations? lines?) going horizontally, which will help keep it stiffer. We used a piece from this big sheet at Lowe’s that lives in the glass section; there are smaller pieces you can get in the hardware section (but they aren’t really cheaper), or just drive around your neighborhood for where someone littered with a “WE BUY HOUSES CASH” sign. (I endorse driving around after an election to pick up the straggler signs the campaigns abandon. We have a stack of them in our shop, and we mocked this up using one of them.)
  • 4x Keystone 4337 brackets, which you can get with your DigiKey PDV. (Honestly, if you aren’t sure what else you want from DigiKey it’s a valid answer to get 300 of these things and just barely use up your voucher. They are great little brackets with a hole already made for #10 hardware. We use them in all sorts of places.)
  • In our hustle to get this done, we may have swapped in slightly longer screws to accommodate the Keystones. We just keep a stash of them in different lengths in our pit, and you should probably work towards the same if you don’t.
  • Two zip ties.

Assembly is probably obvious from the pictures: mount the Keystones to the amp mechanism using the round holes, cut the plastic to size, mark holes with the plastic as far to the left as is legal, then drill four holes, zip-tie through the slotted holes on the other side of the Keystones, and trim the zip ties.

Happy to share any other insight we can provide on this; our season ended last weekend at PCH Charleston, so we aren’t gaining from any secret sauce. Good luck to those still playing!
